results.title: Walking country
results.creator_credit: Conon Fraser, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Mountains and forests cover more than half of New Zealand, and the country is served by a well-maintained network of walking tracks. With its varied scenery, New Zealand offers magnificent walking Country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Conon Fraser, Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit

results.title: Walkabout: the Chauvel's legendary journey...
results.brief_description: Originally produced for British television in 1958 this thirteen part series follows internationally renowned Australian filmmakers Charles Chauvel and Elsa Chauvel on a 3,000 mile journey through Australia. Setting off from Sydney they travel across the Great Dividing Range, heading westward to the outback “dead heart” of Australia through Central Australia and on to the Northern Territory. They look at the outback with all its “bewildering contradictions” - deserts, pasturelands, wide grasslands, opal country, mountain ranges and rivers - join a cattle muster, catch brumbies, observe unique wildlife and visit Aboriginal communities. The series is a time capsule of Australian outback life in the middle of the twentieth century reflecting the attitudes held by white Australians towards Aboriginal peoples and the land at the time. Narrated by Elsa and Charles Chauvel.

results.title: Walk me to the water
results.creator_credit: John Seakwood and St Peter's Hospice
results.brief_description: An intimate portrayal of the experiences of three terminally ill cancer patients being cared for at home. By allowing these patients and those closest to them to tell their own stories, the film conveys a broad range of circumstances, amotions, and insights including the fear and confusion felt by those coping with terminal illness and the strengthening of family bonds that can accompany this distress.

results.title: Walk into wilderness
results.creator_credit: Richard Bennett, Impala Films and Spectangee Productions
results.brief_description: Three young people (Tony Evans, Stewart Graham and Karen Alexander) set out to climb Federation Peak, a rarely climbed mountain in the rugged South West region of Tasmania. The difficulties they encounter en route include bad weather and the dangerous nature of the terrain. After a few days climbing, the trio finally achieve their goal and reach the summit of Federation Peak.

results.title: Walk down any street
results.creator_credit: Bernard Devlin, Victor Jobin and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: In every city, town or village there are cases of human misery and failure that usually remain hidden. But every day a few are thrust into view, to become matters for the police or problems for the social worker. This film demonstrates the work, methods and organisation of a large social agency in the province of Quebec.

results.title: Wales
results.brief_description: Shows not only the beauty and tradition of Wales, but also its agriculture, industries and life of its cities. A panorama if Wales; the landscape and coastline; villages, churches, and chapels; the castles; rock-climbing in Snowdonia; mining and agriculture; heavy industry Cardiff; education and child care; the Eisteddfod and Llangollen.

results.title: Wakefield Express: the portrait of a newspaper
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Anderson, Michael Robinson and Wakefield Express
results.brief_description: Commissioned to celebrate the Wakefield Express newspaper’s fiftieth anniversary. It presents the history and the daily operation of the paper and devotes a central sequence to the subjects which occupy the reporters on the Express and its associated newspapers, the communal life of a group of towns in the West Riding of Yorkshire. We see a training session of the Wakefield Trinity, the local rugby team, and a school concert; a constituency political meeting and the launching of a ship; a carnival in Pontefract; the unveiling of a war memorial in Sharlston. But there is nothing of the impartiality of the “general survey” about the film’s approach: it brings enough concern to the communal activities to view them, in turn, with affection and irony, exasperation and respect. Commentary by George Pootts; camera by Walter Lassally.

results.title: Waiting for water
results.brief_description: An ethnographic film on daily life on the depopulated island of Hatoma in Okinawa, Japan. The soundtrack consists of non-chronological personal diary narration, with the structure of the film containing repetition of events or objects, and images that relate to daily life on the island. From the series “Sink or swim documentaries”.

results.title: Waiting for Harry
results.creator_credit: Kim McKenzie and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Follows the organisation and preparations leading up to the placement of the remains of an Aboriginal male in an elaborately painted hollow log coffin. The deceased was Les Angakarabana, who had died several years earlier, and the burial area was Blyth River, near Maningrida in Arnhem Land.
